dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hey, so I was just reading this really interesting piece about the COVID-19 economy, and it really breaks down, like, the challenges we faced.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hey, so I was just reading this really interesting piece about the C O V I D nineteen economy, and it really breaks down, like, the challenges we faced.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, yeah? The immediate stuff, with the lockdowns and keeping incomes stable, that was wild. Trying to avoid a depression, but not, you know, overdo it with cash.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, yeah? The immediate stuff, with the lockdowns and keeping incomes stable, that was wild. Trying to avoid a depression, but not, you know, overdo it with cash.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The immediate challenge was to maintain consumers incomes in the face of sweeping lockdowns, supply-chain disruptions, and shifts in aggregate supply. This meant striking a balance between avoiding a depression and not goosing the economy with so much liquidity as to turbocharge inflation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! It was a real tightrope. But then, there was this bigger, um, medium-term shift they talk about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! It was a real tightrope. But then, there was this bigger, um, medium-term shift they talk about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: The one where everyone stopped going out and just bought *stuff* online? Like, services just plummeted, especially in-person ones, and goods just exploded.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The one where everyone stopped going out and just bought stuff online? Like, services just plummeted, especially in-person ones, and goods just exploded.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge concerned a broader crisis-induced structural shift away from the purchase of services especially in-person services toward the purchase of durable goods.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. The article said we crammed like, two decades of e-commerce learning into just two years. It felt more comfortable, I guess, consuming at home.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. The article said we crammed like, two decades of e-commerce learning into just two years. It felt more comfortable, I guess, consuming at home.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the height of the pandemic, we crammed a couple of decades worth of societal learning about leveraging e-commerce and the internet into just two years. One takeaway was that doing more of our consuming at home was more comfortable and simply made more sense.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And that gap is still huge, right? Durable goods spending is still way up, like 38% higher, compared to services only being 15% higher. That's a massive difference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And that gap is still huge, right? Durable goods spending is still way up, like thirty eight percent higher, compared to services only being fifteen percent higher. That's a massive difference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, durable-goods spending in real terms is 38% above where it was at the end of March 2018, while services spending is only 15% higher, a 23-percentage-point gap in relative growth.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It is! So, the challenge was how to get workers and firms to respond to that, um, structural shift. Since wages and prices are 'sticky,' as economists say...
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It is! So, the challenge was how to get workers and firms to respond to that, um, structural shift. Since wages and prices are 'sticky,' as economists say...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The medium-term challenge, then, was to create the market incentives to induce workers and firms to respond to this great structural shift in demand. Since neither nominal wages nor prices were going to fall back to their previous levels (they are sticky, in the economic parlance), substantially cutting wages and prices in shrinking service-sector industries was a non-starter.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: You couldn't just cut wages in shrinking sectors. So, you needed inflation in the *new* growing areas, right? To kinda draw people there.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You couldn't just cut wages in shrinking sectors. So, you needed inflation in the new growing areas, right? To kinda draw people there.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Instead, creating more supply in the areas where there was growing demand required wage and price inflation in the newly expanding sectors.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Precisely. It's about letting prices and wages rise where demand was growing. And, um, where are we today with all this?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Precisely. It's about letting prices and wages rise where demand was growing. And, um, where are we today with all this?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, the jobs numbers are looking surprisingly good! We just got that report, like, 326,000 more employed workers than the previous month after revisions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, the jobs numbers are looking surprisingly good! We just got that report, like, three hundred twenty six thousand more employed workers than the previous month after revisions.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, the August number was revised upward by 72,000, which means there are 326,000 more employed workers than in the previous jobs report.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] Yeah, and the unemployment rate is back down to 4.1%! I mean, I remember it being higher not too long ago.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and the unemployment rate is back down to four point one percent! I mean, I remember it being higher not too long ago.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After rising from 3.8% a year ago to 4.3% in July, the unemployment rate is back down to 4.1%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And even better, they revised the income data upwards. Real income coming out of the pandemic was *substantially* higher than we thought.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And even better, they revised the income data upwards. Real income coming out of the pandemic was substantially higher than we thought.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, we also recently learned, following data revisions, that income growth coming out of the pandemic was substantially higher than previously estimated.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Which also means productivity growth since 2020 is going to be revised up. It's like, uh, the economy was stronger than we realized.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which also means productivity growth since twenty twenty is going to be revised up. It's like, uh, the economy was stronger than we realized.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This means that estimated productivity growth since the start of 2020 will be revised upward by about 0.3 percentage points per year, whereas real labor costs will be revised downward by a similar amount.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I know! And remember how worried we all were about the Fed's tightening cycle? Everyone, myself included, thought for sure we were heading for a recession.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I know! And remember how worried we all were about the Fed's tightening cycle? Everyone, myself included, thought for sure we were heading for a recession.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Totally! But... no recession. It's just, like, kept chugging along.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally! But... no recession. It's just, like, kept chugging along.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But there has been no recession, and now I have to think hard about why I was wrong.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, why? Was the fiscal policy just *that* powerful? Or has the neutral rate of interest actually gone up, making the Fed's actions less restrictive than we thought?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, why? Was the fiscal policy just that powerful? Or has the neutral rate of interest actually gone up, making the Fed's actions less restrictive than we thought?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Has the US economy remained so remarkably strong because the effect of expansionary fiscal policy was more powerful than I thought? Or is it because the neutral rate of interest has risen substantially over the past half-decade, implying that the Feds monetary policy has been substantially less restrictive and contractionary than I thought?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Hard to say definitively, but it's been, um, a pretty remarkable soft landing. A lot of silver linings post-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hard to say definitively, but it's been, um, a pretty remarkable soft landing. A lot of silver linings post-pandemic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The post-pandemic economy has had no shortage of silver linings. ... For now, though, we should all enjoy the soft landing that the economy has made.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Definitely. Though, you know, the article does mention potential dark clouds. Like, could this AI boom be, uh, a bubble?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Definitely. Though, you know, the article does mention potential dark clouds. Like, could this A I boom be, uh, a bubble?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The question is whether there are any dark clouds looming on the horizon. One obvious risk is that the ongoing AI boom will prove to be a bubble.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Always something to worry about! But for now, I think we should just, like, enjoy this extraordinary recovery.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Always something to worry about! But for now, I think we should just, like, enjoy this extraordinary recovery.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The recovery from the pandemic has been nothing short of extraordinary.
